text: Hi Steve, I read the entire docs and I'm still confused about what you do. I also clicked around on your website which seems to contradict the docs. The docs says no installation because it is a barrier, on the website I see docs how to install it. The doc starts with one line of code, but I only see multi-line examples. The doc reads more like a business plan than something aimed at users. You can't prove PMF by talking to investors.

text:
Hi all, I plan to share a blog post on Hacker News and wanted to gather some feedback if it is any interesting and if one can follow it - or if not, why not? Would really appreciate any feedback!
<http://feedback.boomla.com/blog/a-filesystem-to-replace-your-cms>

attachments.title: A filesystem to replace your CMS
attachments.fallback: Boomla: A filesystem to replace your CMS

elements.text: Hi all, I plan to share a blog post on Hacker News and wanted to gather some feedback if it is any interesting and if one can follow it - or if not, why not? Would really appreciate any feedback!

text: Interesting! This reminds me a lot of how Zope works (or used to work, back when I worked with it, over a decade ago.) The backing storage was basically a hierarchical db, stored on disk as a btree of pickled python objects.

elements.text: Interesting! This reminds me a lot of how Zope works (or used to work, back when I worked with it, over a decade ago.) The backing storage was basically a hierarchical db, stored on disk as a btree of pickled python objects.

text: <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zope_Object_Database>

attachments.title: Zope Object Database
attachments.text:
The Zope Object Database (ZODB) is an object-oriented database for transparently and persistently storing Python objects. It is included as part of the Zope web application server, but can also be used independently of Zope.
Features of the ZODB include: transactions, history/undo, transparently pluggable storage, built-in caching, multiversion concurrency control (MVCC), and scalability across a network (using ZEO).

text: No it's not optional. It's not a posix filesystem so it's not that you could run it with anything else. I wrote a new kernel around it. So it's basically a new OS. Not that you could boot into it, it runs on an existing OS, giving you a new application platform on top.

elements.text: No it's not optional. It's not a posix filesystem so it's not that you could run it with anything else. I wrote a new kernel around it. So it's basically a new OS. Not that you could boot into it, it runs on an existing OS, giving you a new application platform on top.

text: <@UP448V1PB> you can use it as a static site generator if you want, but you can also edit it via the frontend and have dynamic applications too

elements.text: you can use it as a static site generator if you want, but you can also edit it via the frontend and have dynamic applications too

text: The first versions of the platform were prototyped in PHP, but I abandoned PHP because there was no way to sandbox it. It seems that ZODB only works with python. That sounds like a design mistake to me. Boomla already works with 2 languages, JS and Go, although Go is limited to kernel space (it is written in Go..), but at least there is a guarantee that the kernel APIs are properly in place.

elements.text: The first versions of the platform were prototyped in PHP, but I abandoned PHP because there was no way to sandbox it. It seems that ZODB only works with python. That sounds like a design mistake to me. Boomla already works with 2 languages, JS and Go, although Go is limited to kernel space (it is written in Go..), but at least there is a guarantee that the kernel APIs are properly in place.

text:
Ok I think I understand a bit now. It seems confusing to call it a file system if I can't see the files on my computer outside of your application. 'File system' is also a technical detail that your target audience may not understand or care about.

I'd suggest not partitioning your program from your storage layer initially. Instead focus on what your application enables that would be hard with a database.

elements.text:
Ok I think I understand a bit now. It seems confusing to call it a file system if I can't see the files on my computer outside of your application. 'File system' is also a technical detail that your target audience may not understand or care about.

I'd suggest not partitioning your program from your storage layer initially. Instead focus on what your application enables that would be hard with a database.

text:
> It seems confusing to call it a file system if I can't see the files on my computer outside of your application.

Interesting comment. I guess I'm technically correct (if you write a new OS, and you can't access its filesystem from another OS, it's still a filesystem) but if it gives you the wrong idea it is still wrong. Good point, thank you.

elements.text: It seems confusing to call it a file system if I can't see the files on my computer outside of your application.

Interesting comment. I guess I'm technically correct (if you write a new OS, and you can't access its filesystem from another OS, it's still a filesystem) but if it gives you the wrong idea it is still wrong. Good point, thank you.

text: Rereading the title, it was not obvious that "a filesystem" was what was new here. Why did you build a whole new file system for a CMS? Do you plan other applications using it? Do you plan to make it a complete bootable OS?

elements.text: Rereading the title, it was not obvious that "a filesystem" was what was new here. Why did you build a whole new file system for a CMS? Do you plan other applications using it? Do you plan to make it a complete bootable OS?

text: I want to build a cloud based OS that is super easy to program. The CMS part aims to be the "killer app". There are other kinds of small apps built on top of it. I don't think it needs to be bootable. It could be, but I don't see the benefits.

elements.text: Sorry if you answered this already, but you are looking for feedback anyway, so here it goes. You define Mu as a "computing stack". That's the only definition you give on
, and I may not be your target audience, but I honestly don't know what that means.

text: How do you handle interface changes? That's an interesting topic. I try to keep them immutable in my project, and always introduce new VM instead of changing old interfaces, for example. Then phase the old one out if it's not used any more. Of course, it's not always possible, but works most of the time. It also helps me move faster by not worrying much about breaking things.

elements.text: How do you handle interface changes? That's an interesting topic. I try to keep them immutable in my project, and always introduce new VM instead of changing old interfaces, for example. Then phase the old one out if it's not used any more. Of course, it's not always possible, but works most of the time. It also helps me move faster by not worrying much about breaking things.

text: The disk is append only, all data is stored in merkle trees. If there is a power loss, and the changes are not fully written to disk, the latest valid snapshot will be used.

elements.text: The disk is append only, all data is stored in merkle trees. If there is a power loss, and the changes are not fully written to disk, the latest valid snapshot will be used.

text: Most interesting. So it's versioned! Does the file system keep growing?

elements.text: Most interesting. So it's versioned! Does the file system keep growing?

text: There is the common issue that the response may be sent before the data is persisted. This is not solved yet (just like in most production systems), but I plan to cover this once it runs on a distributed cluster.

elements.text: There is the common issue that the response may be sent before the data is persisted. This is not solved yet (just like in most production systems), but I plan to cover this once it runs on a distributed cluster.

text: Yes the filesystem keeps growing. I have optimized the shit out of it, and you know what, GC is not implemented yet, and I don't even plan to implement it for a while. It's just so efficient.

elements.text: Yes the filesystem keeps growing. I have optimized the shit out of it, and you know what, GC is not implemented yet, and I don't even plan to implement it for a while. It's just so efficient.

This is cool. This isn't just a file system like API. You have most of a real file system.

I think you need a better killer app. There's just so much more you could do with this.

elements.text:
This is cool. This isn't just a file system like API. You have most of a real file system.

text: I mean, every real filesystem is just an API. :slightly_smiling_face: Sure I think it has most of the little details implemented as well. For example, it is check-summed so I can verify the backups that no single bit was damaged. I'm most happy about that, I would literally have a hard time sleeping without disk. The frightening thing is, most mainstream filesystems don't have this.

elements.text: I mean, every real filesystem is just an API.

I'm most happy about that, I would literally have a hard time sleeping without disk. The frightening thing is, most mainstream filesystems don't have this.

text: Oh, btw, I built what I call a Posix Bridge for Boomla. It translates between the Boomla and the Posix filesystem, making it possible for you to use your own tools. There is an SFTP server built into the binary distro that lets one do that. Also, there _was_ FUSE support so that you could mount a Boomla website into a directory. But that was buggy and nobody used it, so I removed it. There is also an import/export capability.

elements.text: Oh, btw, I built what I call a Posix Bridge for Boomla. It translates between the Boomla and the Posix filesystem, making it possible for you to use your own tools. There is an SFTP server built into the binary distro that lets one do that. Also, there
was
FUSE support so that you could mount a Boomla website into a directory. But that was buggy and nobody used it, so I removed it. There is also an import/export capability.

text: Using that, one can literally open an image on the website, draw on it, and save it back. Lots of fun. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Using that, one can literally open an image on the website, draw on it, and save it back. Lots of fun.

text:
I don't have any users yet :smile: so this is still tentative, but the idea is to allow fragmentation of interfaces. Each person's computer should be internally consistent, but different Mu computers may have radical differences, either because their owners modified them or because I changed my mind about something.

Copying software from one instance to another is always assumed to require some manual changes. That's what you have to give up in exchange for avoiding bloat over time.

I have some ideas for tooling to help with this, but like I said it hasn't been a problem yet so they're vaporware.

elements.text: I don't have any users yet

so this is still tentative, but the idea is to allow fragmentation of interfaces. Each person's computer should be internally consistent, but different Mu computers may have radical differences, either because their owners modified them or because I changed my mind about something.

Copying software from one instance to another is always assumed to require some manual changes. That's what you have to give up in exchange for avoiding bloat over time.

I have some ideas for tooling to help with this, but like I said it hasn't been a problem yet so they're vaporware.

text:
I don't care about adoption :slightly_smiling_face:

Mu is chasing longevity. I'll be happy with 200 users by the time I die. But I'd like it to grow past that. Even if it's not called Mu, I want to eventually kill compatibility constraints chasing short term adoption. It's killing for our shared infrastructure heritage.

elements.text: I don't care about adoption

Mu is chasing longevity. I'll be happy with 200 users by the time I die. But I'd like it to grow past that. Even if it's not called Mu, I want to eventually kill compatibility constraints chasing short term adoption. It's killing for our shared infrastructure heritage.

text:
No, that's what I was trying to indicate by "most recent iteration": the Mu repo is 4 years old, and I had a lot more time in the past.

I have a background in processor architecture and compilers. And I'd tried to wrap my head around x86 several times before it finally clicked last year.
